questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with painless, generalized lymphadenopathy and no associated B symptoms. A lymph node biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD10, CD19, CD20, BCL2, and BCL6, and negative for CD5. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of painless, generalized lymphadenopathy along with lymph node biopsy showing centrocytes and centroblasts, and immunohistochemistry positive for CD10, CD19, CD20, BCL2, and BCL6 point towards a diagnosis of follicular lymphoma.


Follicular Lymphoma:

  • Originates from germinal center B-cells.
  • Characteristically associated with t(14;18) translocation, which leads to overexpression of BCL-2, an anti-apoptotic protein.
  • Commonly present as painless, generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • Histology:
    • Shows nodular (follicular) architecture.
    • Contains centrocytes (small cleaved cells) and centroblasts (large cells with open chromatin).
  • Immunophenotype:
    • Positive for CD10, CD19, CD20, BCL-2, BCL-6
    • Negative for CD5
  • Typically follows an indolent course and is considered incurable, with palliative management as the mainstay.

Explanation of other options:

Burkitt Lymphoma (Option B) is characterized by a 'starry-sky' appearance due to high proliferation and tingible body macrophages. It is driven by MYC translocation (t(8;14)), and while BCL2 expression may rarely occur, it is not a defining feature, unlike follicular lymphoma, which consistently shows BCL2 overexpression due to t(14;18).


Diffuse Large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) (Option C) typically shows diffuse sheets of large atypical lymphoid cells, not the nodular/follicular pattern seen in follicular lymphoma. While it may express BCL6, it does not consistently show CD10 and BCL2 co-expression, and CD5 negativity is not diagnostic.


Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) (Option D) exhibits diffuse infiltration by small, mature lymphocytes and commonly shows CD5 and CD23 positivity, which are absent here. It does not originate from germinal center B-cells and is usually negative for CD10, distinguishing it from follicular lymphoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and peripheral neuropathy. His blood pressure is elevated, and laboratory evaluation reveals positive hepatitis B surface antigen and elevated inflammatory markers. A renal biopsy shows segmental transmural inflammation of medium-sized arteries with eosinophilic, fibrin-like deposits in the vessel wall. Which of the following types of necrosis is most likely present?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of abdominal pain, weight loss, neuropathy, hypertension, and hepatitis B positivity point towards a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa, a necrotizing vasculitis of medium-sized arteries. The characteristic type of necrosis seen in this condition is fibrinoid necrosis, due to immune complex-mediated vessel wall damage.

Explanation of other options:

Gangrenous necrosis (Option B): Typically seen in ischemic limbs or intestines, not within blood vessel walls. It presents grossly as black, mummified tissue and is not a microscopic pattern like fibrinoid necrosis.

Fat necrosis (Option C): Seen in acute pancreatitis or traumatic injury to adipose tissue; it involves enzymatic destruction of fat cells and deposition of calcium soaps (saponification), not vasculitis.

Caseous necrosis (Option D): Commonly found in tuberculosis; it features a soft, cheese-like appearance on gross examination, and is histologically distinct from the fibrinoid necrosis seen in PAN.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fatigue and increased skin pigmentation, especially in sun-protected areas. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. A liver biopsy is performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's combination of fatigue, hepatomegaly, and abnormal skin pigmentation especially in sun-protected areas along with the microscopic finding showing hepatocellular iron stained blue with Prussian blue indicates hemochromatosis, a condition of systemic iron overload.

Hemochromatosis:

  • Hereditary Hemochromatosis:
    • A genetic disorder causing excessive iron absorption and accumulation in various organs, leading to progressive tissue damage.
    • Genetics & Epidemiology:
      • Caused mainly by a C282Y mutation in the HFE gene.
      • Inherited in an autosomal recessive
    • Epidemiology:
      • More common in men, as premenopausal women lose iron through menstruation.
  • Secondary (Acquired) Hemochromatosis:
    • Also known as hemosiderosis, it occurs due to:
      • Frequent blood transfusions
      • Chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., thalassemia)
      • Alcohol-related liver disease
      • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Hepcidin, the iron-regulating hormone, is inappropriately low in hereditary cases.
    • This leads to uncontrolled iron absorption from the gut.
    • Iron deposition causes oxidative damage, fibrosis, and increases the risk of liver cancer.
  • Classic Clinical Features (Tetrad):
    1. Liver involvement: Hepatomegaly, progressing to cirrhosis
    2. Skin pigmentation: Bronze or slate-gray tone, especially in sun-exposed areas
    3. Pancreatic damage: Leads to diabetes mellitus
    4. Cardiac issues: Arrhythmias or dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum iron studies: Elevated transferrin saturation and ferritin
    • Genetic testing: Confirms HFE gene mutations
    • Liver biopsy: May be done to assess hepatic iron and fibrosis if needed
    • MRI: Non-invasive assessment of hepatic iron stores
  • Complication: Hepatocellular carcinoma risk is markedly increased up to 200 times higher than normal.

Explanation of other options:

Wilson's Disease (Option A): Typically present in younger individuals with neurologic symptoms and hepatic dysfunction due to copper accumulation. Liver histology may show steatosis, hepatitis, or cirrhosis, with copper deposition confirmed by special stains like rhodanine, not iron overload as in hemochromatosis.

Autoimmune Hepatitis (Option B): Involves autoimmune-mediated liver inflammation, often with elevated liver enzymes and autoantibodies (ANA, SMA). Histology shows interface hepatitis, not iron overload.

Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (Option C): Can cause liver disease but is characterized by PAS-positive globules in hepatocytes due to defective protein accumulation, not iron deposition.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease is admitted with severe dyspnea. Despite supportive care, she dies on the third day of hospitalization. At autopsy, the mitral valve is examined and shown below. What is the most likely cause of these valvular changes?
questions.solution:
The 'fish-mouth' or 'buttonhole' appearance is characteristic of mitral stenosis, the most common valvular lesion in chronic rheumatic heart disease, resulting from leaflet thickening, commissural fusion, and chordal shortening.

Rheumatic Heart Disease:

  • Gross Findings:
    • Mitral valve most commonly affected (followed by aortic).
    • Leaflet thickening, fusion of commissures, and fusion and shortening of chordae tendineae.
    • Classic "fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis of mitral valve.
    • May see atrial enlargement (due to mitral stenosis), ventricular hypertrophy, and mural thrombi.
  • Microscopic Findings:
    • Aschoff bodies: Pathognomonic lesions consisting of:
      • Central fibrinoid necrosis.
      • Surrounding inflammatory infiltrate including Anitschkow cells (macrophages with slender, wavy "caterpillar-like" nuclei).
    • Pancarditis (can involve all layers of the heart).
    • Chronic phase shows fibrosis and neovascularization of valves, leading to permanent deformities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a painless thyroid nodule noticed during a routine check-up. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathology image shows characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei, clear, empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin, commonly seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC):

  • It is the most common thyroid malignancy, with a strong predilection for lymphatic spread, especially to cervical lymph nodes.
  • Patients typically present with a painless thyroid nodule or midline neck swelling, sometimes with lymphadenopathy.
  • Genetic Associations:
    • Frequently linked to BRAF mutations
    • May also involve RET/PTC gene rearrangements
  • Histopathological Hallmarks:
    • True papillae: Branching structures with central fibrovascular cores
    • Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nuclei due to finely dispersed chromatin
    • Nuclear grooves: Longitudinal grooves giving a "coffee bean" appearance
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI): Cytoplasmic material invaginated into the nucleus
    • Psammoma bodies: Concentric, round calcific deposits (a form of dystrophic calcification)
  • Prognosis:
    • Among all thyroid cancers, papillary carcinoma has the most favorable prognosis.

Explanation of other option:

Follicular carcinoma (Option A) does not show Orphan Annie nuclei or psammoma bodies. Instead, it features uniform follicles and is diagnosed based on capsular or vascular invasion, which cannot be reliably assessed by FNAC alone. It typically spreads via the bloodstream, not lymphatics.

Toxic nodular goitre (Option C) is a benign condition marked by hyperfunctioning thyroid nodules that often present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as palpitations or weight loss. Histologically, it lacks nuclear changes seen in malignancies and instead shows colloid-filled follicles without papillary features.

Medullary carcinoma (Option D) arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with calcitonin secretion, sometimes leading to diarrhea or flushing. Histology typically reveals amyloid stroma and polygonal tumor cells, not the clear nuclei or papillary architecture characteristic of PTC.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents with hematuria and lower limb edema. On examination, his blood pressure is within normal limits. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine level of 9 mg/dL, and his blood glucose is normal. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below.Which of the following investigations would be most useful in identifying the underlying cause of this histologic finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hematuria, pedal edema, and elevated serum creatinine along with crescent formation on renal biopsy point toward a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Detection of circulating anti-GBM antibodies is crucial for confirming RPGN caused by anti-GBM antibody-mediated injury.

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

  • A clinical syndrome marked by rapid loss of renal function (over days to weeks), usually associated with crescent formation in most glomeruli on biopsy.
  • Classification of RPGN:
    • Type I: Anti-GBM Antibody-Mediated
      • Caused by autoantibodies targeting the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)
      • May involve lungs in Goodpasture syndrome (pulmonary hemorrhage + nephritis)
      • Immunofluorescence (IF): Linear IgG and C3 deposition along GBM
    • Type II: Immune Complex-Mediated
      • Involves deposition of immune complexes within the glomeruli
      • Common causes:
        • Post-infectious glomerulonephritis
        • Lupus nephritis
        • IgA nephropathy
        • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis)
      • IF pattern: Granular ("lumpy-bumpy" or "starry sky") due to immune complex deposition
    • Type III: Pauci-Immune (ANCA-Associated): M/c type
      • Little or no immune deposition on IF
      • Associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs)
      • Common entities:
        • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's)
        • Microscopic polyangiitis
        • Idiopathic cases
      • IF finding: Minimal to no deposits
  • Histological Features:
    • Crescents: Formed by proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration by monocytes and macrophages
    • Electron Microscopy: Shows rupture and distortion of GBM
  • Diagnostic Tools:
    • Anti-GBM Antibodies: Specific for Goodpasture syndrome
    • ANCA Testing: Useful in pauci-immune vasculitis
    • Complement levels & ANA: To assess lupus or post-infectious causes

Explanation of other options:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) (Option A): Useful in diagnosing autoimmune diseases like lupus, which can cause immune complex glomerulonephritis. However, the biopsy pattern here is more consistent with anti-GBM disease.

HIV RNA (Option C): HIV-associated kidney disease is most commonly linked to collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (HIVAN), particularly in patients of African descent. However, HIV can rarely cause immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, but crescentic glomerulonephritis is not typical, making HIV RNA less relevant here compared to anti-GBM antibodies.

Urine immunoelectrophoresis (Option D): Primarily used to detect monoclonal proteins in disorders like multiple myeloma and amyloidosis. These are not typically associated with crescent formation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old individual presents with persistent diarrhea, signs of malabsorption, and a decreased appetite. Duodenal biopsy reveals villous flattening, elongation of crypts, and an increased presence of CD8+ lymphocytes within the lamina propria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of malabsorption, along with duodenal biopsy findings showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytosis, are characteristic of celiac disease.

Celiac Disease:

  • Celiac disease is a chronic immune-mediated condition precipitated by the ingestion of gluten in individuals with genetic susceptibility.
  • It primarily affects the small intestine, resulting in mucosal damage and nutrient malabsorption.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms of malabsorption, including diarrhea, weight loss, abdominal discomfort, and fatigue.
    • Poor appetite and growth failure may also be observed in younger individuals.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serologic Testing:
      • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (anti-tTG) antibodies - high sensitivity
      • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA) - high specificity
    • Histopathology (Duodenal Biopsy):
      • Villous atrophy
      • Crypt hyperplasia
      • Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, especially CD8+ T cells
      • Chronic inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria
    • Treatment: Strict gluten-free diet

Explanation of other options:

Environmental enteropathy (Option A): A disorder common in developing regions due to repeated exposure to enteric pathogens. It causes chronic inflammation and some mucosal changes, but does not show the specific triad of villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and CD8+ infiltration seen in celiac disease.

Whipple's disease (Option C): A rare systemic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei, presenting with malabsorption, arthritis, and neurologic symptoms. The biopsy typically shows foamy macrophages that are positive for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain, which is not a feature of celiac disease.

Chronic pancreatitis (Option D): This condition leads to digestive enzyme deficiency and subsequent malabsorption. However, histology of the small intestine remains unremarkable in these cases. Pancreatic imaging or function tests are more useful for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and occasional episodes of nausea and vomiting. On examination, he is pale. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. A peripheral blood smear image is shown below. Based on the clinical findings and peripheral smear, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, along with peripheral smear findings of macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils, point toward a diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia, most likely due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 Deficiency:

  • Commonly present as macrocytic anemia, often showing macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear.
  • One major underlying mechanism is impaired absorption, often due to autoimmune atrophic gastritis in pernicious anemia, which reduces intrinsic factor production, or other causes like H. pylori-associated gastritis.
  • Common Causes of Vitamin B12 Deficiency
    1. Inadequate Intake
      • Strict vegetarian or vegan diet
      • Chronic alcoholism
    2. Increased Physiological Demand
      • Pregnancy
      • Lactation
      • Rapid growth in children
    3. Malabsorption or Impaired Absorption
      • Pernicious anemia
      • Gastrectomy
      • Ileal diseases
      • Ileal resection
      • Chronic pancreatitis
      • Bowel diverticulosis
      • Parasitic infections, especially Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm)

Explanation of other options:

Folate deficiency (Option B): Also causes macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils but does not result from atrophic gastritis. Unlike B12 deficiency, neurological signs are absent. It's common in alcoholics, pregnancy, and poor nutrition.

Pyridoxine deficiency (Option C): Leads to microcytic anemia, often seen with isoniazid use or alcoholism. It does not present with hypersegmented neutrophils or gastric mucosal changes.

Niacin deficiency (Option D): Causes pellagra, which presents with the triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is unrelated to macrocytic anemia or changes in blood cells seen here.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought in with complaints of painless rectal bleeding and a mass that prolapses during defecation. The lesion was excised, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a prolapsing rectal mass with painless rectal bleeding in a young child, along with the histopathological findings of cystically dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris in an inflamed stroma, point toward the diagnosis of a juvenile polyp.

Juvenile Polyps:

  • These are hamartomatous growths characterized by mucosal overgrowth, typically presenting as isolated lesions or, less commonly, as part of juvenile polyposis syndrome.
  • Frequently seen in children under 5 years old
  • May occur as isolated lesions or as part of hereditary syndromes
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Arise due to mucosal overgrowth (hamartomatous nature)
    • In juvenile polyposis syndrome, mutations in the SMAD4 or BMPR1A genes (part of the TGF-β signaling pathway) are implicated
  • Morphological Features:
    • Size: Generally <3 cm
    • Shape: Usually pedunculated with a smooth, reddish surface
    • Gross Appearance: May exhibit cystic spaces due to dilated glands
  • Microscopic Features:
    • Glands: Dilated, mucus-filled glands
    • Lamina Propria: Contains a mix of inflammatory cells
    • Muscularis mucosae: May appear thinned or disrupted
  • Dysplasia & Malignancy Risk:
    • Sporadic juvenile polyps: Low risk of dysplasia or malignancy
    • Syndromic cases (juvenile polyposis syndrome): Increased risk of developing colorectal adenocarcinoma

Explanation of other options:

Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (Option A): Typically associated with mucocutaneous pigmentation and polyps with arborizing smooth muscle cores, which are absent here.

Villous Adenoma (Option B): Seen in adults, these show villiform architecture and are often sessile with a higher malignant potential.

Tubular Adenoma (Option D): These polyps are more glandular and found in older patients; they do not typically show cystic dilation of glands.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of chronic cough with sputum production, progressive dyspnea, and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a recent lobar pneumonia. She was neither a smoker nor an alcoholic. The autopsy image of her lung is shown below. What is the most likely underlying cause of the pathological findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young non-smoker with progressive respiratory symptoms and the autopsy revealing diffuse enlargement of airspaces throughout the acinus suggests panacinar emphysema, which is strongly linked to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (AATD):

  • Genetics:
    • Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
    • Caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene located on chromosome 14.
  • Common Genotypes:
    • Normal: PiMM
    • Carrier: PiMZ
    • Deficient: PiZZ (most severe form)
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Leads to reduced levels or dysfunction of alpha-1 antitrypsin, a protease inhibitor that protects tissues from neutrophil elastase.
    • Lung involvement: Early-onset panacinar emphysema, especially in the lower lobes.
    • Liver involvement: Abnormal AAT protein accumulates in hepatocytes → can cause neonatal hepatitis, cirrhosis, and increased HCC risk.




Explanation of other options:

Cystic fibrosis (Option B) usually presents earlier in life with mucus plugging and bronchiectasis, not panacinar emphysema.

Mutation in dynein arms (Option C) causes primary ciliary dyskinesia with recurrent infections, but not emphysematous changes.

Antibodies against type IV collagen (Option D) are associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and crescentic glomerulonephritis, not the panacinar emphysematous changes seen in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with fatigue and massive splenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation reveals anemia, a total leukocyte count of 150,000/μL, and a peripheral smear showing 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Bone marrow examination reveals a myeloid-to-erythroid ratio of 18:1. Which of the following investigations is the most sensitive for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical findings, including marked leukocytosis, basophilia, and massive splenomegaly, are classic for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The most sensitive and specific investigations to confirm this diagnosis are FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) and PCR.


Explanation of other options:

Immunophenotyping (Option A): Useful for classifying acute leukemias and lymphoid malignancies based on cell surface markers but does not detect the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which is crucial for diagnosing CML.

Flow cytometry (Option D): Excellent for identifying lymphoid vs. myeloid lineages and for acute leukemias, but it cannot detect chromosomal translocations like t(9;22), which are essential in confirming CML.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with fatigue, gum bleeding, and fever for 2 months. Laboratory investigations reveal severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 3 g/dL, leukopenia with a total leukocyte count of 1500/μL,, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 15,000/μL,. The peripheral smear shows macrocytic red cells, and the reticulocyte count is low at 0.5%. A bone marrow biopsy is performed and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of prolonged gum bleeding, pallor, and fever, along with peripheral smear findings of macrocytosis and low reticulocyte count, and bone marrow showing hypocellularity with fatty infiltration and absence of immature cells, point towards a diagnosis of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

Aplastic Anemia:

  • Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure, causing reduced production of all blood cell lines (pancytopenia).
  • In advanced cases, the marrow becomes markedly hypocellular, often yielding a dry tap on aspiration.

  • Low reticulocyte count (0.5%) reflects severely impaired hematopoiesis, distinguishing aplastic anemia from hemolytic anemias, which typically show elevated reticulocytes due to compensatory marrow activity.
  • Histologically, the marrow is replaced by adipose (fat) tissue with an absence of immature precursor cells.
  • This fatty replacement reflects severely diminished hematopoietic activity typical of aplastic anemia.

Explanation of other options:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option B): Typically presents with hemolytic anemia, hemoglobinuria (especially in the morning), and flow cytometry reveals CD55/CD59 deficiency, not consistent with the hypocellular marrow seen here.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (Option C): Shows dysplastic changes in hematopoietic cells with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow, which contrasts with the fatty, hypocellular marrow seen in aplastic anemia.

Tuberculosis (Option D): While TB can rarely cause bone marrow suppression, it usually shows granulomatous inflammation rather than complete marrow fat replacement and absence of hematopoietic cells.

Reference:

NIH Link

questions.text: A middle-aged male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption presents with abdominal distension. Physical exam reveals shifting dullness and a reduced liver span. A liver biopsy shows hepatocytes containing dense, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. What is the primary component of these cytoplasmic inclusions?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of ascites and shrunken liver in a chronic alcoholic, along with histology showing intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions, is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. These inclusions, known as Mallory-Denk bodies, are composed of intermediate filaments, specifically cytokeratins

Mallory-Denk Bodies (Mallory Hyaline Bodies):


  • These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in hepatocytes.
  • They are made up of intermediate filaments, primarily cytokeratin 8 and 18.
  • Commonly associated with alcoholic liver disease, but also seen in other hepatic conditions.
  • Conditions associated with Mallory-Denk bodies (Mnemonic: N-I WATCH):
    • N: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
    • I: Indian childhood cirrhosis
    • W: Wilson';s disease
    • A: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
    • T: Tumors of the liver (especially hepatocellular carcinoma)
    • C: Chronic cholestatic liver diseases
    • H: Hepatic (Primary) biliary cirrhosis (not typically seen in secondary biliary cirrhosis)

Explanation of other options:

Actin (Option B): Though a cytoskeletal protein, actin forms microfilaments and does not aggregate in this fashion in hepatocytes.

Microtubules (Option C): Involved in intracellular transport and mitosis, but not in the formation of Mallory bodies.

Fibronectin (Option D) is an extracellular matrix protein involved in cell adhesion and tissue repair, not a component of cytoplasmic inclusions like Mallory-Denk bodies, which are composed of intermediate filaments.

choices.text: Telomere length increases progressively with age
Activation of telomerase accelerates cellular aging
Progressive telomere shortening contributes to aging
Telomere length remains unchanged in somatic cells over time

questions.text: According to the telomerase theory of aging, which of the following is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Progressive shortening of telomeres in somatic cells limits their ability to divide, contributing to cellular aging. The telomerase enzyme, which counteracts this shortening, is inactive in most somatic cells, supporting the telomerase theory of aging.

Telomerase Theory of Ageing:

  • Telomere length is considered a biomarker of ageing; as cells divide, telomeres progressively shorten.
  • Consequence of Telomere Shortening: Shortened telomeres can lead to cellular senescence, contributing to ageing and age-related diseases.
  • Function of Telomerase: Telomerase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase that adds nucleotide repeats to the ends of chromosomes, preserving telomere length.
  • Activity in Cells: Although active in stem cells, germ cells, and cancer cells, telomerase activity declines in most somatic cells with age. (Option D)
  • Impact of Decreased Telomerase: Reduced telomerase function leads to progressive telomere shortening, loss of chromosomal stability, and eventual cell cycle arrest or apoptosis. (Option C)
  • Critical Telomere Length: Once telomeres reach a critical minimum length, they fail to protect chromosomes, promoting genomic instability and cellular dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

Telomere length increases progressively with age (Option A): This is incorrect because telomere length actually decreases with each cell division over time, which contributes to aging, not the reverse.

Activation of telomerase accelerates cellular aging (Option B): Activation of telomerase actually counteracts cellular aging by maintaining telomere length, allowing continued cell division, as seen in stem cells or cancer cells. It does not accelerate aging.

questions.text: A child presents with repeated respiratory infections, abdominal discomfort, and delayed growth. He also has facial changes attributed to bone involvement. On examination, icterus and a palpable spleen are noted. The hemoglobin electrophoresis is shown below. Based on the clinical and lab findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of recurrent infections, abdominal symptoms, stunted growth, jaundice, and mild splenomegaly in a child suggests an inherited hemoglobinopathy. The electrophoresis pattern showing elevated fetal hemoglobin (HbF) with little or no adult hemoglobin (HbA) supports the diagnosis of thalassemia major.

Thalassemia:

  • A hereditary condition affecting the synthesis of hemoglobin chains.
  • Leads to microcytic, hypochromic anemia due to defective hemoglobin formation.
  • Hemoglobin is composed of 2 alpha (α) and 2 beta (β)
  • Types Based on Genetic Mutation:
    • Alpha Thalassemia: Mutation in α-globin gene.
    • Beta Thalassemia: Mutation in HBB gene on chromosome 11 affecting β-chain production.
    • Inherited in an autosomal recessive

Explanation of other options:

HbC disease (Option B): Generally milder; Hb electrophoresis shows increased HbC, not HbF, and growth is usually normal.

Sickle cell disease (Option C): Characterized by high HbS levels on electrophoresis, with features like painful crises and vaso-occlusion, which aren't seen here.


Acute coronary disease (Option D): Unlikely in a child and doesn't match the presentation of chronic hemolytic anemia or electrophoresis findings.

questions.text: A child presents with intermittent episodes of jaundice and splenomegaly. Family history reveals similar symptoms in an elder sibling. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
A child presenting with intermittent jaundice, splenomegaly, and a family history of similar symptoms, along with a peripheral smear showing round, dense red blood cells without central pallor (spherocytes) is highly suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. The osmotic fragility test confirms hereditary spherocytosis by demonstrating increased RBC fragility in hypotonic solutions, with sensitivity enhanced by incubating RBCs prior to testing.

Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS):

  • An inherited hemolytic anemia caused by defects in red blood cell (RBC) membrane proteins leading to spheroidal, less deformable RBCs.
  • Genetics:
    • Autosomal dominant (∼75% of cases): Commonly involves ankyrin
    • Autosomal recessive: Often associated with spectrin mutations.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Mutations in ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2 disrupt RBC membrane stability.
    • Loss of membrane surface area leads to decreased surface-to-volume ratio.
    • RBCs adopt a spherical shape to maintain volume.
    • These spherocytes are rigid and become trapped in the splenic sinusoids.
    • Trapped cells undergo extravascular hemolysis in the spleen.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Classic triad: Anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly.
    • Other features:
      • Neonatal jaundice
      • Hemolytic episodes
      • Pigment gallstones (late complication)
      • Rarely, iron overload in chronic cases
  • Peripheral Smear Findings:
    • Spherocytes: Small, round RBCs lacking central pallor.
    • Reticulocytosis: Indicates compensatory marrow response.

Explanation of other options:

Coombs test - Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (Option B): The Coombs test detects antibodies or complement on red cell surfaces and is used to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), where spherocytes may also be seen. However, AIHA is typically acquired (not familial) and presents acutely, unlike the chronic hereditary pattern seen here.

Genetic testing - G6PD deficiency (Option C): G6PD deficiency is an X-linked enzymopathy present with episodic hemolysis triggered by infections or certain drugs, and the smear typically shows bite cells or Heinz bodies, not spherocytes. Also, there is no chronic splenomegaly or family history involving both genders in most cases.

Flow cytometry - Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option D): Flow cytometry is the diagnostic test of choice for PNH, which presents with intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and sometimes thrombosis, not isolated splenomegaly or spherocytes. It is an acquired clonal disorder, not familial.

questions.text: A young boy from Africa presents with a rapidly enlarging swelling of the jaw. A biopsy of the lesion was performed, and the histological section is shown below. Cytogenetic analysis reveals a translocation t(8;14). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a jaw mass in an African child, along with t(8;14) translocation and the classic "starry sky" appearance in histology, is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma.

Burkitt Lymphoma:

  • Type: Highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Genetic Basis: Strongly associated with MYC gene rearrangements, especially t(8;14); other translocations include t(2;8) and t(8;22).
  • Histopathology: Classic "starry sky" appearance due to tingible body macrophages (containing apoptotic debris) dispersed among malignant lymphocytes.
  • EBV Association:
    • Found in nearly all endemic cases (~100%).
    • Seen in ~20% of sporadic and ~25% of immunodeficiency-associated
  • Subtypes of Burkitt Lymphoma:
    1. Endemic Type:
      • Typically occurs in children in malaria-endemic African regions.
      • Frequently presents with tumors in the jaw, orbit, or facial bones.
      • Strong EBV association (almost all cases).
    2. Sporadic Type:
      • More common in Western countries.
      • Often involves the abdomen, especially the ileocecal area.
    3. Immunodeficiency-Associated Type:
      • Seen in HIV/AIDS or post-transplant patients.
      • May affect lymph nodes or CNS.

Explanation of other options:

Acute myeloid leukemia (Option A): Involves the bone marrow and peripheral blood, not usually a jaw mass or t(8;14).

Follicular lymphoma (Option B): Shows t(14;18) translocation and has a slower progression, not typical in children or with jaw tumors.

Multiple myeloma (Option C): A plasma cell malignancy seen in older adults, typically presents with bone pain, not facial masses in children.

questions.text: A child presents with puffiness around the eyes, cola-like urine, and elevated blood pressure. Laboratory results reveal an initial serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL, which increases to 4.5 mg/dL over the next three weeks despite therapy. What is the most likely electron microscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of gross hematuria (cola-colored urine), edema, hypertension, and rising creatinine are classic for post-infectious glomerulonephritis, particularly following streptococcal infection (PSGN). On electron microscopy, the most distinctive finding is the presence of subepithelial, dome-shaped electron-dense deposits, often described as "humps."

Pathological Features of Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

  • Gross Appearance:
    • The kidneys show a mottled or speckled surface, often described as a "flea-bitten" appearance, due to multiple small petechial hemorrhages.

  • Light Microscopy:
    • Glomeruli appear hypercellular, caused by:
      • Proliferation of mesangial and endothelial cells.
      • Infiltration by inflammatory cells, particularly neutrophils and monocytes.
  • Electron Microscopy:
    • Presence of subepithelial, dome-shaped, electron-dense deposits.
    • These are classic "hump-like" deposits, representing immune complexes lodged beneath podocytes.

  • Immunofluorescence:
    • Shows granular immune complex deposition along the glomerular basement membrane.
    • Produces a "starry sky" pattern, reflecting scattered IgG and C3 deposition.

Explanation of other options:

Subendothelial deposits (Option A): More commonly associated with lupus nephritis or membranoproliferative GN, not PSGN.

Crescent formation (Option C): Crescent formation is a light microscopy finding in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, not an electron microscopy feature. It is not characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which typically shows subepithelial humps on EM.

Mesangial deposits (Option D): Characteristic of IgA nephropathy or MPGN, but not the hallmark of PSGN on EM.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the hospital with fever, fatigue, and signs of left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy was performed and is shown below. Based on the clinical features and the biopsy findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of systemic symptoms (fever, fatigue) and left ventricular dysfunction, along with a biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltrates, is most consistent with lymphocytic myocarditis.

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

  • An inflammatory disorder of the myocardium marked by predominant lymphocyte infiltration, often due to a viral or autoimmune trigger.
  • Common Causes:
    • Viral infections (e.g., Coxsackievirus, adenovirus, parvovirus B19)
    • Autoimmune conditions (e.g., SLE, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Post-viral immune reactions
    • Idiopathic (no identifiable cause in some cases)
  • Pathological Findings:
    • Lymphocytic infiltration primarily involving the myocardium, often affecting the left ventricle
    • Myocyte damage or necrosis due to immune-mediated injury
    • Fibrosis and scarring seen in chronic or healing stages
    • Progression in severe or unresolved cases may result in dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Clinical Course & Prognosis:
    • Mild cases can resolve spontaneously with supportive care
    • Severe inflammation may cause heart failure, arrhythmias, or dilated cardiomyopathy
    • In end-stage disease, heart transplant may be required

Explanation of other options:

Acute rheumatic fever (Option A): Would show Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells on histology, and often follows a streptococcal throat infection.

Chagas cardiomyopathy (Option B): Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, seen in endemic areas (mainly South America); biopsy shows amastigotes inside myocytes.

Pyogenic myocarditis (Option C): Typically caused by bacterial infections; characterized by neutrophilic infiltration and abscess formation, not lymphocytes.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6198272/

questions.text: An elderly man undergoes a routine check-up and is found to have a markedly elevated total leukocyte count. His peripheral blood smear shows the cells depicted in the image below. What would be the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear findings particularly the presence of fragile lymphocytes known as smudge cells in an elderly individual with a high total leukocyte count (TLC) are strongly suggestive of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). The next most appropriate step in confirming this diagnosis is flow cytometry, a technique that identifies the specific cell surface markers present on lymphocytes.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)

  • Genetic Basis:
    • Common chromosomal abnormalities: Trisomy 12, Deletion 13q14, and others.
    • Cells originate from post-germinal center memory B-cells or naive mantle zone B-cells.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • BCL2 overexpression inhibits apoptosis, leading to accumulation of B-cells.
    • BTK (Bruton Tyrosine Kinase) is essential for malignant B-cell survival.
    • Not associated with radiation exposure.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most frequent leukemia in elderly individuals.
    • Often incidentally discovered during routine blood tests.
    • Symptoms (if present) may include:
      • Fatigue
      • Generalized lymphadenopathy
      • Hepatosplenomegaly
      • Recurrent infections due to immune dysfunction
    • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia may occur, look for spherocytes in PBS.
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common, increasing infection risk.
      • Infections are the leading cause of death in CLL.
  • Laboratory Findings
    • ALC (Absolute Lymphocyte Count) > 5000/mm³.
    • Bone marrow infiltration by lymphocytes >30%.
    • Smudge cells (fragile lymphocytes disrupted during smear preparation) are characteristic of peripheral smear.
  • Flow cytometry findings:
    • Positive for CD19, CD20 (B-cell markers)
    • Co-expression of CD5 (normally a T-cell marker)
    • CD23 positivity helps distinguish CLL from mantle cell lymphoma

Explanation of other options:

Stem cell transplantation (Option A): Reserved for relapsed/refractory or aggressive disease. Not used as an initial diagnostic tool.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option B): May be helpful in staging or assessing marrow involvement but is not required to confirm diagnosis. Flow cytometry is preferred.

High-dose chemotherapy (Option D): Not first-line in early-stage or asymptomatic patients. Treatment initiation depends on symptoms, cytopenias, or disease progression; targeted therapy is now preferred over high-dose chemo.

questions.text: A patient who received four units of blood within the past two hours now reports chest discomfort. A chest radiograph reveals bilateral interlobar fissure thickening. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms occurring soon after receiving multiple blood units along with chest discomfort and radiographic signs of pulmonary congestion, point toward transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). This condition results from the infusion of blood products at a rate or volume that exceeds the patient's cardiovascular capacity to handle the fluid load.

Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO):

  • Leading cause of transfusion-related mortality, especially with a reduction in TRALI cases.
  • Predisposing Factors:
    • Elderly patients
    • Impaired kidney function
    • Baseline fluid overload
    • Heart failure or poor cardiac function
    • Large volume transfusions
    • Fast transfusion rates, exceeding patient's cardiovascular capacity
  • Clinical Features:
    • Shortness of breath, decreased oxygen saturation
    • Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest imaging (alveolar pattern)
    • Hypertension, typically systolic
    • Raised BNP (Brain Natriuretic Peptide)
    • Low-grade fever may be present
  • Prevention Strategies:
    • Screen for risk factors prior to transfusion.
    • Monitor high-risk individuals closely during transfusion.
    • Slow transfusion rate (e.g., 1 unit RBCs over 3-4 hours).
    • Consider prophylactic diuretics in stable patients with prior TACO episodes.
  • Management:
    • Discontinue transfusion immediately if symptoms arise.
    • Provide oxygen supplementation.
    • Use diuretics to relieve fluid overload and prevent worsening symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

ABO incompatibility reaction (Option A): Presents rapidly (within minutes to hours) with fever, chills, hypotension, back pain, and hemoglobinuria due to acute intravascular hemolysis, not pulmonary congestion.

Hypocalcemia (Option C): Can occur after massive transfusions due to citrate in stored blood binding calcium. Symptoms include paresthesias, tetany, or cardiac arrhythmias, not typically pulmonary congestion.

Graft-versus-host disease (Option D): Occurs days to weeks after transfusion, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Presents with rash, liver dysfunction, pancytopenia, and diarrhea, not acute chest symptoms.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with fatigue, hypercalcemia, renal impairment, and anemia. Laboratory tests show a monoclonal spike on serum protein electrophoresis, and immunofixation results are provided below. Which of the following best describes the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and a monoclonal spike on serum protein electrophoresis, along with immunofixation showing elevated IgM levels, is consistent with IgM-type Multiple Myeloma, a rare but recognized variant of plasma cell neoplasm.


Explanation of other options:

Multiple myeloma with increased IgG (Option A): Incorrect because immunofixation in this case shows elevated IgM, not IgG. Although IgG is the most common subtype of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma with increased IgA (Option C): Although IgA is the second most common subtype of multiple myeloma, this case specifically shows elevated IgG on immunofixation. IgA myeloma also often forms aggregates or rouleaux, and may present with more hyperviscosity than IgG types.

Monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (Option D): Characterised by M-protein spike and absence of end-organ damage (no CRAB features). This patient clearly has CRAB findings, excluding Monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (MGUS).

questions.text: Based on the pedigree shown below, which of the following conditions is most likely inherited in this pattern?
questions.solution:
The absence of male-to-male transmission in the pedigree (since males pass their Y chromosome to sons) supports X-linked recessive inheritance, as seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

  • Only males affected: consistent with X-linked recessive transmission.
  • Carrier females: typically unaffected but can pass the affected X chromosome to male offspring.
  • No male-to-male transmission: sons receive the Y chromosome from their father, not the affected X.

X-Linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "WISE-ABCDEFGH")

  • W - Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
  • A & B - Hemophilia A and Hemophilia B
  • B - Bruton's Agammaglobulinemia
  • C - Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red-Green Color Blindness
  • D - Duchenne and Becker Muscular Dystrophy
  • E - Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome
  • F - Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome
  • G - G6PD Deficiency
  • H - Hunter Syndrome

Explanation of other options:

Wilson disease (Option B) is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both sexes are equally affected and there is no sex-linked pattern.

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) (Option C) results from a paternal deletion or maternal uniparental disomy on chromosome 15, not from an X-linked inheritance.

Achondroplasia (Option D) follows an autosomal dominant pattern, often appearing in every generation regardless of sex.

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the bone marrow

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow examination reveals 22% plasma cells. A biopsy section of the tissue is shown below. Based on the clinical and histological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of hepatosplenomegaly, increased plasma cells in the marrow, and the deposition of amorphous pink material on histology representing amyloid deposits strongly suggests a diagnosis of primary amyloidosis.

Systemic Amyloidosis:

  1. Primary Amyloidosis (AL Type):
    • Commonly associated with monoclonal plasma cell disorders, including multiple myeloma.
    • Amyloid deposits are composed of immunoglobulin light chains (mostly λ, occasionally κ).
    • These light chains or their fragments (especially N-terminal parts) aggregate to form AL (amyloid light chain) fibrils.
    • Monoclonal plasma cells secrete excess free light chains that can be detected as Bence Jones proteins in the urine.
  2. Secondary Amyloidosis (AA Type):
    • Develops as a consequence of chronic inflammatory conditions such as:
      • Rheumatoid arthritis
      • Inflammatory bowel disease
      • Chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis)
    • Fibrils are composed of AA (amyloid A) protein, derived from serum amyloid A, an acute-phase reactant produced by the liver during inflammation.
  3. Transthyretin (ATTR) Amyloidosis:
    • Results from deposition of misfolded transthyretin (TTR) protein, a normal serum carrier of thyroxine and retinol-binding protein.
    • Two forms:
      • Hereditary ATTR: Caused by mutations in the TTR gene.
      • Wild-type ATTR (senile systemic amyloidosis): Occurs with age, even without genetic mutation.
    • Organs primarily affected include the heart (causing restrictive cardiomyopathy) and peripheral nerves (leading to neuropathy).

Explanation of other options:

Myxoid Degeneration of the Bone Marrow (Option A) involves gelatinous changes in bone marrow, typically associated with severe nutritional deficiency or chronic systemic disease, and does not show amyloid-like deposition.

Plasma Cell Leukemia (Option C) is a rare malignancy characterized by large numbers of plasma cells circulating in the blood, but it presents with widespread systemic signs rather than local amyloid deposition.

Hemolytic Anemia (Option D) involves accelerated destruction of red blood cells and would not produce the pink, acellular deposits seen in this biopsy.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with a distended abdomen, chronic diarrhea, progressive visual impairment, and neurological abnormalities. His peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of malabsorption symptoms, visual disturbances, neurologic findings, and a peripheral smear demonstrating acanthocytes (spur cells) is most consistent with abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia:

  • Cause:
    • Caused by mutations in the MTTP gene (Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein).
    • MTTP is essential for assembling and secreting lipoproteins containing apolipoprotein B in the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Lipid Profile Abnormalities:
    • Marked reduction in plasma cholesterol and triglyceride levels.
    • Defective formation of chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Typically presents in early life with:
      • Poor growth
      • Chronic diarrhea
      • Fat malabsorption leading to steatorrhea
      • Deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K)
      • Visual impairment results from vitamin E deficiency, leading to retinitis pigmentosa-like retinal degeneration.
  • Blood Smear Findings:
    • Shows acanthocytosis - red blood cells with irregular, spiked membranes.

Explanation of other options:

Whipple's disease (Option B) is caused by Tropheryma whipplei infection and typically features malabsorption and neurologic involvement, but it is not associated with acanthocytosis or lipid metabolism defects.

Menetrier's disease (Option C) involves overgrowth of the gastric mucosa with protein loss, often resulting in edema rather than diarrhea or neurological signs; blood smear findings are unrelated.

Uremia (Option D) results from advanced renal dysfunction and may cause neurological symptoms, but it does not produce acanthocytes or lipid absorption issues.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive shortness of breath, chest tightness, and a chronic dry cough. He has worked in an industrial setting for over two decades. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial fibrosis, and the biopsy image provided below shows characteristic histological changes. Based on the clinical history and histopathology, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of a history of prolonged occupational exposure, respiratory symptoms, diffuse lung fibrosis on X-ray, and biopsy findings of dumbbell-shaped asbestos bodies is classic for asbestosis.

Asbestosis:

  • A form of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers over prolonged exposure.
  • Pathogenesis: Pleural plaque (1st lesion) → Pleural nodule → Asbestos/ferruginous body formation → Asbestos fiber deposition → Iron accumulates around fibers → Lung cancer
  • Gross:
    • Widespread interstitial fibrosis of the lungs.
  • Microscopy:
    • Presence of asbestos bodies.
    • These appear as golden-brown rods and are indicative of prior asbestos exposure.
  • Types of Asbestos Fibers:
    • Chrysotile (serpentine): Most common form.
    • Amphibole: Less common but more carcinogenic.
  • Complications / Sequelae:
    • Localized or diffuse pleural fibrosis.
    • Pleural effusions.
    • Progressive parenchymal fibrosis (i.e., asbestosis).
    • Increased risk of lung carcinoma and mesothelioma.
    • Possible development of extrapulmonary cancers (e.g., laryngeal, ovarian, colonic).

Explanation of other options:

Silicosis (Option A): Usually present with small upper lobe nodules and "eggshell" calcification of lymph nodes; biopsy shows silica-laden macrophages, not asbestos bodies.

Anthracosis (Option B): Seen in coal workers, characterized by carbon pigment accumulation in macrophages without the golden-brown, rod-shaped bodies seen in asbestosis.

Byssinosis (Option C): Caused by inhaling cotton dust, typically affecting textile workers, and is associated with chest tightness early in the workweek ('Monday fever'), not interstitial fibrosis or asbestos body formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male football player collapses during a match and is brought to the emergency department in cardiac arrest. Despite resuscitation efforts, he is declared dead. Histopathological examination of cardiac tissue is performed and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of sudden cardiac arrest in a young athlete, along with the biopsy finding of disorganized (helter-skelter) myocardial fibers, strongly points toward hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).


Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM):

  • Genetic Basis:
    • Caused by mutations in genes coding for sarcomeric proteins.
    • Most of the mutations are missense mutations.
    • Frequently affected genes include:
      • MYH7 (β-myosin heavy chain)
      • MYBPC3 (myosin-binding protein C)
      • Cardiac troponins (TnT, TnI)
      • α-tropomyosin
  • Key Features:
    • Marked thickening of the myocardium, especially of the interventricular septum.
    • The left ventricle becomes stiff and less compliant.
    • Diastolic dysfunction due to impaired ventricular filling.
    • May exhibit intermittent obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • It is the most common cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.
    • Recognized as a major cause of sudden cardiac death in adolescents and young adults, especially athletes.

Explanation of other options:

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option B): This condition involves ventricular dilation and weakened contraction, but histology shows scattered interstitial fibrosis and enlarged, stretched myocytes, not the disorganized pattern seen in HOCM.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option C): Primarily characterized by stiff ventricles due to fibrosis or infiltrative processes like amyloidosis, this condition presents with reduced ventricular compliance, not myocyte disarray.

Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (Option D): This mostly affects the right ventricle and is marked by fatty or fibrofatty infiltration of myocardium, which is distinct from the myofibrillar disorganization of HOCM.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient reports to the clinic with gradual abdominal distention and episodes of low-grade fever. Laboratory investigations show a normal peripheral blood smear. A mass was excised, and histopathology of the involved lymph node is shown in the image below. Based on the histological findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of systemic symptoms such as abdominal fullness and fever, normal peripheral smear, and histological features showing disrupted lymph node structure with increased blood vessels is consistent with Castleman disease.

Castleman Disease:

  • A rare disorder marked by abnormal proliferation of lymphoid tissue; can affect a single lymph node (unicentric) or multiple nodes (multicentric).
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Persistent or recurrent fever
    • Abdominal swelling or discomfort, often due to enlarged intra-abdominal lymph nodes
    • Chronic fatigue
    • Involuntary weight loss
    • Night sweats
    • Palpable lymphadenopathy, commonly in the neck, mediastinum, or abdomen
    • Breathlessness when enlarged nodes press on thoracic structures
    • Anemia
    • Fluid accumulation or swelling (edema) in limbs or other areas
  • Histological Features:
    • Disorganized lymph node structure
    • Prominent vascular proliferation within nodal tissue
    • Sometimes shows "onion-skin" appearance of mantle zones (in hyaline-vascular type)

Explanation of other options:

Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma (Option A) is a peripheral T-cell lymphoma characterized by systemic symptoms, lymphadenopathy, and polymorphic infiltrates with prominent vascularity in histology. It lacks the 'onion-skin' mantle zones or hyaline-vascular features of Castleman disease.


Hodgkin's lymphoma (Option B): While it involves lymph nodes and may present with similar systemic symptoms, it is classically identified by Reed-Sternberg cells, which are absent in the biopsy findings described here.


IgG-4-related disease (Option C): This is a systemic inflammatory condition affecting multiple organs and usually shows dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates with fibrosis and elevated IgG4+ plasma cells. The presentation and histopathological details are not typical for this condition in this case.


Reference: Castleman Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male dies one day after experiencing chest discomfort that radiated to his left arm. Autopsy findings reveal a significant atheromatous obstruction in the left anterior descending coronary artery. What type of tissue calcification is most likely present in this case?
questions.solution:
Dystrophic calcification is a frequent finding in atherosclerotic plaques, where calcium deposits form in necrotic or degenerate tissue without requiring elevated serum calcium levels, as seen in this case.

Dystrophic Calcification:

  • Deposition of calcium salts in damaged or necrotic tissues, not associated with systemic calcium imbalance.
  • Serum Calcium Levels: Normal in dystrophic calcification. (Option A)
  • Common Sites:
    • Atheromatous plaques in advanced atherosclerosis
    • Damaged or aging heart valves, worsening their function over time
  • Gross Appearance: Fine, white granules or gritty areas visible on the affected tissue surface.
  • Microscopic Features (H&E stain):
    • Basophilic (blue-purple), irregular granular material
    • May appear as clumps within necrotic areas
    • Psammoma bodies: Small, round, laminated calcific formations that resemble concentric rings ("onion-skin" pattern). Seen in:
      • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
      • Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
      • Meningioma
      • Prolactinoma
      • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
      • Mesothelioma

Metastatic Calcification: (Option B & D)

  • Deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues due to elevated serum calcium levels.
  • Common Causes:
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH)
    • Bone destruction/resorption (e.g., metastases, multiple myeloma)
    • Vitamin D excess (overdose, sarcoidosis)
    • Chronic renal failure (secondary hyperparathyroidism)
    • Others:
      • Aluminum toxicity (e.g., in dialysis patients)
      • Milk-alkali syndrome (excessive calcium/alkali intake)

questions.text: A woman presents with knee pain and implant loosening after undergoing total knee replacement surgery a few years ago. Histopathological analysis of the surrounding tissue is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with joint pain and implant loosening following knee replacement, and histology shows foreign body giant cells with metallic debris. These findings are characteristic of metallosis, a complication of metal-on-metal prosthetic wear.

Metallosis:

  • A condition involving tissue reaction to metal debris from metal-on-metal (MoM) implants.
  • Leads to aseptic fibrosis, necrosis, and loosening of the prosthesis.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Wear and corrosion of metal implants (e.g., cobalt, chromium, titanium) release metallic particles.
    • These particles induce:
      • A foreign body giant cell response
      • Inflammation and cytokine release
      • Tissue damage and necrosis
    • Absorbed metal ions may lead to systemic complications like:
      • Peripheral neuropathy
      • Cardiomyopathy
      • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Clinical Features:
    • Local symptoms:
      • Persistent joint pain
      • Swelling
      • Formation of pseudotumors
      • Skin discoloration around the implant site
    • Systemic symptoms:
      • Neurologic: tingling, numbness
      • Cardiac: rhythm disturbances
      • Endocrine: hormonal imbalances
  • Diagnosis:
    • Blood tests: Elevated serum cobalt and chromium
    • Imaging: MARS MRI (Metal Artifact Reduction Sequence) to detect pseudotumors
    • Histopathology:
      • Pigment-laden macrophages
      • Foreign body-type giant cells
      • Evidence of metal debris and necrosis
  • Metallosis must be distinguished from septic loosening, which requires microbiological cultures to exclude infection, in addition to imaging and histopathology.
  • Management:
    • Ongoing surveillance of metal ion levels and clinical symptoms
    • Revision surgery using non-metallic or alternative implants when necessary

Explanation of other options:

Ochronosis (Option A): Typically occurs due to homogentisic acid buildup in alkaptonuria. Leads to black pigmentation of cartilage and connective tissue but is not associated with implants or foreign body-type inflammation.


Malignant melanoma (Option C): A malignancy of melanocytes presenting as dark pigmented skin lesions. While melanin may appear dark histologically, melanoma does not feature foreign body giant cells or metallic debris.


Rosai-Dorfman disease (Option D): A rare histiocytic disorder involving massive lymphadenopathy. Characterized histologically by emperipolesis (intact lymphocytes within histiocytes) rather than metal debris or prosthetic-related changes.


Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4750564/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9075182/

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a palpable mass in her left breast. A biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemistry is used to evaluate HER2/neu expression. The stained tissue section shows strong membranous staining of tumor cells, as seen in the image. Which chromogen was most likely used to produce this brown coloration?
questions.solution:
3,3'-Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is the chromogen most commonly used in immunohistochemistry (IHC). It produces a brown precipitate upon reacting with peroxidase enzymes, aiding the visualization of antigen-antibody binding such as HER2 overexpression in breast cancer.


Diaminobenzidine (DAB):

  • Commonly used chromogen in immunohistochemistry (IHC), particularly for detecting markers like HER2 in breast carcinoma.
  • Acts as a substrate for the peroxidase enzyme attached to antibodies (primary or secondary).
  • Undergoes oxidation, resulting in the formation of an insoluble brown-colored polymer.
  • The brown precipitate highlights the location of the target antigen, enabling visual detection under a microscope.

Explanation of other options:

FITC (Fluorescein Isothiocyanate) (Option A) is a green fluorescent dye used in immunofluorescence, not IHC.

Phycoerythrin (Option B) is a red-orange fluorescent dye used in flow cytometry and fluorescence microscopy.

Cyanine dye (Option C) are fluorescent tags used for labeling biomolecules in fluorescence microscopy or molecular techniques, not for producing brown chromogenic reactions in immunohistochemistry.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5775208/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557663/

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with repeated bluish discoloration of her hands, tightness of the skin, difficulty swallowing, and evidence of lung involvement. Her ANA (antinuclear antibody) test reveals a specific staining pattern as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis and associated ANA pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms including Raynaud phenomenon (recurrent bluish discoloration), skin tightening (sclerodactyly), swallowing difficulty (esophageal dysmotility), and lung involvement are classic features of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The anti-centromere antibody pattern is highly specific for limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), while diffuse systemic sclerosis is more commonly associated with anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies.

Scleroderma:

  • A rare autoimmune connective tissue disorder marked by excess collagen deposition, resulting in skin tightening and organ fibrosis.
  • Epidemiology:
    • More common in females
    • Peak incidence typically between 50 to 60 years of age
  • Types of Scleroderma:
  1. Localized Scleroderma
    • Affects only the skin
    • Commonly involves fingers, forearms, and face
  2. Systemic Sclerosis
    • Involves both skin and internal organs
    • Further classified into two major subtypes:

questions.text: Match the following tumors with their associated markers:

A 34-year-old man presents with intermittent episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating. On examination, he has a marfanoid body habitus, including a sunken chest and disproportionately long limbs. Soft tissue growths are observed on his tongue, and a palpable mass is noted in the left flank. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient shows signs of pheochromocytoma (palpitations, headache, and sweating), mucosal neuromas (tongue growth), and a marfanoid body habitus, all classic features of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2B (MEN 2B).


Explanation of other options:

Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (Option D): Presents with vestibular schwannomas and CNS tumors, not with endocrine tumors or mucosal neuromas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, weight loss, and early satiety. On examination, he has pallor and massive splenomegaly. Blood tests reveal anemia and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. The peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and marrow fibrosis in an anaemic, splenomegaly patient strongly indicates Primary Myelofibrosis, a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm. Teardrop cells (dacrocytes) are a hallmark of primary myelofibrosis, resulting from mechanical distortion as RBCs pass through a fibrotic bone marrow or rigid spleen.

Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF):

  • A type of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm.
  • Characterized by progressive bone marrow fibrosis leading to disrupted hematopoiesis.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Fibrosis is induced by fibrogenic cytokines such as platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-β.
    • These are released from abnormally proliferating megakaryocytes.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Progressive anemia
    • Massive splenomegaly
    • Constitutional symptoms: fatigue, weight loss, night sweats

WHO Diagnostic Criteria for PMF:

  • Major Criteria:
    1. Megakaryocytic proliferation and atypia with accompanying reticulin or collagen fibrosis.
    2. Exclusion of other myeloid neoplasms such as CML (BCR-ABL1+), PV, ET, and MDS.
    3. Presence of one of the following mutations:
      • JAK2
      • CALR
      • MPL
      • If negative: Evidence of clonal markers or exclusion of reactive fibrosis.
  • Minor Criteria (supportive):
    • Leukocytosis ≥11 × 10⁹/L.
    • Elevated LDH (serum lactate dehydrogenase).
    • Unexplained anemia.
    • Palpable splenomegaly.

Explanation of other options:

Polycythemia vera (Option A): Typically presents with increased RBC mass, not anemia.

Essential thrombocythemia (Option B): Characterized by markedly raised platelet count without marrow fibrosis.

Chronic myeloid leukaemia (Option D): Shows increased granulocytes and Philadelphia chromosome, not prominent fibrosis or teardrop cells.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5807384/

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought in with a 6-month history of increasing clumsiness. On examination, the left eye shows leukocoria and lacks the normal red reflex. Imaging reveals an intraocular mass, and the affected eye is surgically removed. Microscopic examination of the tumor is shown below. Genetic testing reveals defective regulation of the cell cycle. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of leukocoria, absent red reflex, and progressive visual symptoms, along with microscopy showing Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (circular arrangements of tumor cells around a central lumen), point towards a diagnosis of Retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma:

  • Most common primary intraocular tumour in children.
  • Age of Onset:
    • Typically appears before 3 years of age.
    • Sporadic (non-heritable) cases are usually diagnosed within the first year.
  • Molecular Pathogenesis
    • Caused by mutations in the RB1 tumour suppressor gene located on chromosome 13q14.
    • Tumour formation occurs when both RB1 alleles are inactivated, resulting in unregulated retinal cell growth.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) - most frequent initial sign.
    • Strabismus due to vision loss.
    • Proptosis and orbital involvement in late stages.
    • Can progress to metastasis if untreated.
  • Histopathology
    • Tumor composed of small, round, blue cells (indicative of primitive neuroectodermal origin).
    • Areas of necrosis with tumour cell anastomosis.
    • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes seen in well-differentiated forms (circular arrangements of tumour cells around a central lumen).

Explanation of other options:

Wilms tumour (Option A): This pediatric kidney cancer commonly presents as a painless abdominal mass, sometimes accompanied by blood in the urine or high blood pressure. Microscopically, it features a mix of immature kidney components: blastemal, stromal, and epithelial elements.


Ependymoma (Option C): A tumor arising from ependymal cells lining the ventricles, especially the fourth ventricle in children, often causing symptoms of raised intracranial pressure such as vomiting and headache. Histology typically reveals perivascular pseudorosettes and occasionally true rosettes.


Neuroblastoma (Option D): A tumor derived from neural crest cells, usually found in the adrenal glands or sympathetic ganglia, often presenting with an abdominal mass and signs like periorbital bruising or rapid eye movements. On microscopy, it shows Homer Wright rosettes and stains positive for neuronal markers such as chromogranin and synaptophysin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a one-month history of left knee pain. Examination reveals localized tenderness over the joint. Imaging (X-ray) of the knee demonstrates a 5 cm lytic lesion in the distal femoral epiphysis showing a characteristic "soap bubble" appearance. A biopsy is performed, and a histological section is shown below. Based on the clinical findings and the histopathological image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a lytic, expansile epiphyseal lesion with a soap-bubble radiographic pattern and numerous osteoclast-like giant cells on histology strongly indicates Giant Cell Tumour (Osteoclastoma).

Giant Cell Tumour (Osteoclastoma):

  • Benign but locally aggressive bone tumors.
  • Contains numerous osteoclast-type multinucleated giant cells.
  • Age Group:
    • Commonly affects individuals between 30-50 years of age.
  • Common Site:
    • Typically arises in the epiphysis of long bones and may extend into the metaphysis.
    • Distal femur and proximal tibia (around the knee) are the most frequent locations.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Tumour arises from immature osteoblast precursors.
    • These neoplastic cells overexpress RANKL, leading to:
      • Increased recruitment and maturation of osteoclast precursors.
      • Excessive bone resorption due to hyperactive osteoclasts.
  • Radiological Appearance:
    • Shows a soap-bubble or lytic appearance on X-ray.
  • Potential for Metastasis:
    • Rarely spreads to lungs; if it does, may regress on its own.
    • Despite aggressive local behaviour, rarely life-threatening.
  • Gross Morphology:
    • Appears as a large, red-brown mass.
    • Frequently shows cystic changes on gross examination.
  • Microscopic Features:
    • Composed of mononuclear stromal cells intermixed with:
      • Numerous osteoclast-like giant cells, often with >100 nuclei.
    • Stroma is uniform and contains oval tumour cells.

Explanation of other options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A): A benign tumour found in the epiphysis, but usually occurs in adolescents. Shows immature cartilage and "chicken-wire" calcification rather than giant cells.


Osteosarcoma (Option C): A high-grade malignant tumour seen in children and young adults, usually in the metaphysis, not the epiphysis. X-ray shows a sunburst pattern or Codman triangle, not soap bubble.

Osteochondroma (Option D): A benign, cartilage-capped bony projection near growth plates. Typically arises from the metaphysis, not the epiphysis, and lacks the lytic, expansile features of osteoclastoma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with painless scrotal swelling. Blood investigations reveal elevated LDH levels, while AFP remains within normal limits. He undergoes orchidectomy, and the histological section from the excised testicular mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of painless testicular swelling, normal AFP, elevated LDH, and histology showing large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli strongly points to a diagnosis of seminoma.

Seminoma:

  • Most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • Ovarian counterpart: Dysgerminoma
  • CNS counterpart: Germinoma (e.g., pineal gland)
  • Epidemiology
    • Typically affects men in their 30s to 40s (peak in the 4th decade)
  • Genetic & Molecular Markers
    • Contains isochromosome 12p
    • Expresses OCT3/4, NANOG, CD117 (c-KIT)
  • Gross Morphology:
    • Appears as a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated mass
    • No haemorrhage or necrosis typically observed
  • Histological Features
    • Composed of sheets of uniform cells
    • Lobular architecture, divided by fibrous septa
    • T-cell lymphocytic infiltration in the septa
    • Tumour cells:
      • Large, round to polyhedral
      • Prominent central nucleus with 1-2 nucleoli
      • Clear or watery cytoplasm (rich in glycogen)
      • Distinct cell borders
  • Seminomas are highly radiosensitive, making radiotherapy a key treatment modality, in addition to orchidectomy, for localized disease.

Explanation of other options:

Yolk Sac Tumor (Option A): Typically seen in young children with elevated AFP and shows Schiller-Duval bodies (perivascular structures) on histology.


Teratoma (Option B): Presents with mature or immature tissues from multiple germ layers and lacks the uniform clear cells seen in seminoma.


Embryonal carcinoma (Option D): Aggressive tumour with elevated AFP or β-hCG; histology reveals pleomorphic cells with indistinct borders, often with hemorrhage and necrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual reports experiencing persistent headaches, seizures, and progressive neurological deficits over the past few weeks. Neuroimaging reveals a large brain lesion with necrotic areas and poorly defined margins. A biopsy confirms a high-grade malignant tumour. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and also the most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The clinical features, imaging with central necrosis and irregular margins, and biopsy showing high-grade malignant features point toward glioblastoma, the most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults.

Glioblastoma (GBM):

  • Origin: Arises from astrocytes; classified as WHO Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • Epidemiology: Most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Rapidly progressive symptoms
    • Headache, seizures
    • Cognitive decline, focal neurological deficits
  • Neuroimaging:
    • MRI typically shows ring-enhancing lesions
    • Perilesional oedema is often present
  • Histopathology:
    • High mitotic activity
    • Microvascular proliferation
    • Necrosis with pseudopalisading tumour cells
    • Presence of glomeruloid bodies (vascular structures resembling renal glomeruli)


  • Treatment: Standard chemotherapy includes temozolomide.
  • Prognosis: Generally poor due to aggressive and infiltrative nature.

Explanation of other options:

Medulloblastoma (Option A): This tumour primarily affects children, especially in the cerebellum, and is uncommon in adults.

Meningiomas (Option B) are common benign primary brain tumors, typically arising from the meninges. However, glioblastoma is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults, characterized by necrosis and infiltrative growth.

Retinoblastoma (Option C): This is a paediatric intraocular tumour, not a primary brain tumour, and presents with features like leukocoria. It is unrelated to intracranial malignancies in adults.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a firm, irregular mass located in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. On clinical examination, the lump is non-tender and poorly circumscribed. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the image and clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a firm, irregular breast lump along with the histopathology showing dyscohesive cells in an Indian file pattern point towards a diagnosis of Invasive Lobular Carcinoma.

Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC):

  • Genetic Basis:
    • Associated with CDH1 gene mutation, resulting in loss of E-cadherin, a key adhesion molecule.
    • Same mutation is also noted in signet ring cell carcinoma of the stomach.
  • Clinical Characteristics:
    • Often presents as a firm, irregular lump in the breast, typically in the upper outer quadrant.
    • Frequently bilateral and multicentric - evaluation of the opposite breast is essential.
  • Microscopic Features:
    • 'Indian file' pattern results from loss of E-cadherin, causing dyscohesive tumor cells to infiltrate in single rows, a hallmark of invasive lobular carcinoma."
    • Minimal desmoplastic response and limited fibrosis seen.
    • Targetoid spread: tumour cells encircle uninvolved ducts.
    • Pagetoid spread: tumour cells infiltrate the epithelium of ducts.
    • May show signet ring cells with scant mucin in some cases.
  • Metastatic Pattern:
    • Has the potential to metastasize to the peritoneum and leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis).
  • Prognosis:
    • Generally has a favourable outcome with appropriate treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Phyllodes tumours (Option A): A fibroepithelial neoplasm presenting as a fast-growing, well-circumscribed breast lump. Histology shows increased stromal overgrowth with leaf-like architecture, unlike the infiltrative pattern of ILC.


Inflammatory breast carcinoma (Option B): Presents acutely with skin erythema, thickening, and peau d'orange appearance due to dermal lymphatic invasion, features not seen in this case.

Fibroadenoma (Option D): A common benign tumour in younger women, usually mobile, painless, and well-circumscribed. Microscopy shows proliferative fibrous tissue with compressed ducts, not the infiltrative "indian-file'' pattern.
